users.description: User who wants to be heard and understood, values emotional connection

conversation.content: I've been feeling really down lately and I don't know why.
I'm sorry to hear that. Would you like to talk about it?
I guess... I just feel like no one really listens to me. Everyone always wants to fix things.
That sounds frustrating. It's important to feel heard.
Yeah, exactly. I don't need solutions, I just need someone to understand what I'm going through.
I hear you. Sometimes we just need space to express ourselves.
My family doesn't get it. They always say 'just be positive' or 'think about the good things.'
That kind of response can feel dismissive when you're struggling.
It really does. I appreciate when someone just sits with me and lets me feel what I feel.
That's a valid need. Being present with someone is powerful.
I'm a teacher, so I spend all day giving to others. When I come home, I'm emotionally drained.
Teaching can be incredibly draining emotionally.
I just want this to be a safe space where I can share without judgment.
Absolutely. This is your space to be yourself.

users.test_message: I had a really hard day with my students and I'm feeling emotionally exhausted.

users.description: User who is introspective, notices their thought patterns, wants to understand themselves

conversation.content: I've been noticing that I always assume the worst about situations.
That's an interesting observation. Can you give me an example?
Like if my boss doesn't reply to an email, I immediately think I did something wrong.
That sounds like you're jumping to conclusions. What evidence do you have for that thought?
I mean, none really. My boss is just busy. But my brain goes there anyway.
It's interesting that you recognize the pattern.
I want to understand why I think this way. I'm curious about my own patterns.
Self-awareness is a great first step.
I think it comes from childhood—always trying to read my parents' moods.
That makes sense. Early experiences can shape our automatic thoughts.
I'd like to explore these patterns more. Maybe understand the stories I tell myself.
That's a thoughtful approach.
I'm an analyst by profession, so I like to understand the data—even when it's about myself.
Applying that analytical lens to yourself can be powerful.

users.test_message: My manager gave me feedback today and I immediately thought I'm terrible at my job.

users.description: User with high anxiety who dislikes cheerful advice, needs calming presence

conversation.content: Ugh, I've been feeling pretty overwhelmed with work lately.
That sounds tough. What's been going on?
I'm a software engineer and the deadlines just keep stacking up.
That kind of pressure can build really quickly.
I usually work late into the night. I'm most productive after midnight.
Late-night focus works well for some people.
But then my sleep gets messed up and I feel anxious the next day. It's a cycle.
That sounds frustrating—being productive but dealing with the fallout.
You know what? I really don't like overly cheerful advice when I'm stressed. It feels fake.
I hear you. Forced positivity can feel dismissive.
Sometimes I just want someone to listen instead of fixing things.
Being heard without pressure to solve everything can be important.
I want this to feel like a steady presence, not a life coach trying to optimize me.
That makes sense. I'm here to support, not to push.

users.test_message: I've been working past midnight again and the anxiety is building up.

users.description: User who is action-oriented, wants concrete steps, prefers practical solutions

conversation.content: I need to get better at managing my time. I'm always behind.
Time management can be tricky. What's been the main challenge?
I take on too much and then I can't deliver. I need a system.
Having a system can definitely help.
I'm not looking for emotional support here—I just want practical solutions.
Got it. Let's focus on actionable steps.
Exactly. Give me something I can do today, not next month.
Small, immediate actions can build momentum.
I'm a project manager, so I'm used to plans and deadlines. I work well with structure.
Structure sounds like it aligns with how you operate.
I prefer direct communication. Don't sugarcoat things for me.
I appreciate that directness. I'll keep it straightforward.
If something isn't working, I'd rather know so I can fix it.
That problem-solving mindset is valuable.

users.test_message: I have three deadlines this week and I don't know where to start.
